DIV1.P: Imperial Gratitude, Drawn from a Modest View OF THE CONDUCT OF THE Emperor CH...ES VI.
AND THE King of Spain CH...ES III.
With OBSERVATIONS on the Difference, &c. Being a far∣ther View of the Deficiencies of our Confederates.
LONDON: Printed in the Year 1712.

DIV1.HEAD: PREFACE, Directed to those who are for Carrying on this WAR.
DIV1.P: WE are not here enquiring into, or ma∣king Reflections upon, those who for private Ends of their own, whether Party Ends, or Personal, are, or have been, for prolonging the War.

The popular Objection is, that we are bound not to enter into any Treaty with the Enemy without Consent of our Allies, and the first and Principal Person in the Alliance is the Em∣peror, who refuses to come to this Treaty or to make Peace with F ance, and without him you ought not to attempt it.

The Reasons why the Emperor insists thus against a Treaty are needless to be Discoursed, since his Answer is positive; and as his Impe∣rial Majesty Expresses in his l etter to the Elector Palatine, quoted in these Sheets, his Resolution for the War is irrevocable. Now
what signifies Discussing Reasons, when the Party declares himself fix'd, and irrevocable?

The following Sheets are a brief Calculation of the Conduct and the Management of our Glorious Ally, the Emperor particularly in his Spanish Capacity, from whence the Reader, by drawing such Inferences as are suitable to the Honour of his Queen, and his Country, and those who would continue the War, purely to gra∣tifie, serve, and oblige, an Ally, may see here what they have to expect from him, and for what kind of Treatment the Blood and Treasure of this Kingdom, which they would so lavishly bestow, is to be expended. It is hoped the Considera∣tion of this may a little move them, which if it should, the Author of these Sheets will think the Time and Labour very well bestowed.

DIV1.HEAD: Imperial Gratitude.
DIV1.P: THE Title of this Book seems so well to direct the Reader to the Design, that it stands in need of very little Introduction. The Endea∣vour us'd of late to extol and advance the Interest and Conduct of the Emperor, as the most Considerable of the Allies, and Powerful enough to do Great Things of himself, so as to make his present Conduct the Rule by which to direct and judge of Publick Affairs, makes it necessary to enquire a little into these Things; and state them indifferently to the World, that Peo∣ple may no more be impos'd upon about them: To which Purpose we are at present to enter a little into the Conduct of the Person now sitting on the Imperial Throne in his past and present Capacity, confi∣ning our Enquiry, however particularly, to what relates to him as an Ally, and as his Conduct respects Her Majesty, the Queen of Great-Britain.

Previous to this it may fall in our Way to enquire or speak a little of the last Emperors Father and Brother, to the Present, and of the Empire itself, of both only with Respect to the Grand Alliance, and the Succession to the Crown of Spain.

Subsequent to this it may fall in the Way to say something to the Conduct of Her Majesty, the Queen of Great-Britain, as it relates to the Person of the present Empe∣ror, and the Interest of the last, and the Obligations which one of them may be under to the other.

These Things lead us to make this Book very much a Search into History, and will fill it with some Original Papers, which every one may not have seen; it will be obvious to every observing Eye whether his Imperial Majesty has return'd a reci∣procal Kindness, or shewn a suitable Re∣spect to Her British Majesty for the Kind∣ness and Services he has received: In doing this we shall only proceed to lay down Matter of Fact, without passing our own Judgment therewith: It shall be in no one's Power to charge us with Indecency to, and Reflection on, his Imperial Majesty, the Application of all being left by Way of Question to every Reader to make for himself.

In Pursuit therefore of this Just Enquiry, we must, First, Enter a little into the History of the Emperor, and Empire itself as it re∣lates
to the Grand Alliance, where without any Impartiality we shall see, whether it has not been the constant Care and Concern of the Queen of England to promote the Interest of the Emperor, not as Emperor only, but even the Family Interest of the Emperor, as Head of the House of Austria.

The First Testimony we have of this, is in the very Beginning of the Grand Alli∣ance, on which the present War was found∣ed, and is now carried on; where the Interest of his Imperial Majesties House is made an Essential Article of the said Alliance; and no Peace is to be made till the Emperor receive Satisfaction for his Pretensions to the Crown of Spain; as in the Eight Article of the said Alliance is express'd thus. An Equitable and Reasonable Satisfaction to his Imperial Majesty for his Pretensions to the Dominions of the Spanish Monarchy, &c. and the like in the Second Article. Vid. the Treaty.

It is to be noted here, that at the Time of making this Alliance, the French King having set up his Grandson Philip on the Throne of Spain upon the Pretensions, and by such Arts and Management, of which History is full; the Emperor having a ma∣nifest Right to the Succession of Spain, and resolving to put in his said Claim, prepared for War.

The Confederates, who were every one preparing at the same Time to attack France for the New Attempts which he had made, in Breach of the Treaty of Partition, had every one their several Pretensions. The Dutch for the Loss of their Barrier; the English for the Danger of their Com∣merce, and the Setting up a Pretender; the King of Prussia his Offensive Treaties, and the like; and all were the more willing to put their Demands together, that they might mutually assist each other in One General War and Confederacy: To this End a Congress was appointed at the Hague to concert their respective Claims, and form a Grand Alliance, by which they might go on upon France, as a United Body, that one might not taste of good or bad Success with∣out the other. This was in the Year 1702.

When this Meeting was first made, the Debate was not, who should, or should not, possess the Spanish Monarchy, this was not en∣tred into in the least; only in general a Sa∣tisfaction was to be given to his Imperial Majesty for his Pretensions, as above; and therefore those Authors, who contend that this Satisfaction to be given his Imperial Majesty was nothing but putting the said Monarchy into his Hands, are so far in the Wrong; and it was urged in the said Con∣gress what was formerly in the Treaty of Partition made by King William. (viz.) That in Order to prevent too many Domini∣ons
falling into the Hand of any One Prince, therefore—&c. (viz.) The same Person was never to be Emperor and King of Spain, or King of France and King of Spain, at the same Time; in Consequence of which Debate, it was agreed, that the Emperor should take it for Satisfaction, that the Monarchy of Spain should be consign'd over by him, and be by the Allies engaged to the next Prince of his House, which was upon the Consideration before mentioned, (viz.) that the Imperial Crown, and that of Spain, ought not to be at one and the same Time, in one and the same Person. This we mention here, not to concern this Tract in any of the Common Debates, which make so much Noise in the Publick Prints; but as it necessarily comes to be mentioned here, in order to clear up the Point, how, and by what Means, the Per∣son of the present Emperor, being then Arch-duke Charles of Austria, and no more, came to be named to the Crown and Do∣minions of Spain.

The Person who named him first, and whose Schemes gave the first Birth to this Proposition, was the Almirant de Castile, a Prince of the greatest Penetration into the Affairs of Spain, and who was at this Time fled from Spain into Portugal, whose Con∣duct in those Affairs was so fatal to the French Faction, that Means was soon found, as we have heard suggested, to convey him
into another World. But as soon as the Queen of England, (for then the Union was not,) receiv'd the Proposal, Her Ma∣jesty especially espoused the Interest of this Young Prince, and by Her Ambassador at Vienna so far concerned herself in his Behalf, as also with the other Confederates, that the said Arch-duke Charles was de∣clar'd King of Spain at Vienna 12th of September, 1703, N. S. by his Father, the Emperor Leopold, and his Brother Joseph, King of Hungary, afterwards Emperor; who for themselves, and their other Heirs, solemnly resign'd their Right and Claim to the same; and as these Things are not left upon Record to every Eye, it may not be improper to give you this short Abridgment of the Manner of it.

DIV2.HEAD: Vienna, September 18th, 1703.
DIV2.P:
UPON the 12th of this Instant, in the Morning, the Emperor and the King of the Romans Sign'd, and Swore, to an Act, by which they both resign'd all their Right and Claim to the Spanish Monarchy, in Favour of the Arch-duke Charles. The same Day, about Four in the Afternoon, all the Privy-Councellors were summon'd to the Council-Chamber, where the Emperor, the King of the Romans, and the Arch-duke, were pre∣sent:
At what Time the Emperor made a short Speech, importing, That the Branch of the House of Austria in Spain being Extinct by the Death of the Deceas'd King Charles the Second, that Monarchy with the Domini∣ons annex'd to it, were devolv'd upon him; and therefore being importun'd by his Illustri∣ous Confederates, and among the rest, by the Queen of Great-Britain, and the King of Portugal, to provide a Successor to that Mo∣narchy, he had thought fit to send over to Spain his Second Son, the Arch-duke Charles, in order to be put into Possession of the said King∣dom, and the Dominions thereunto belonging. To which Purpose his said Imperial Majesty, and the King of the Romans, had thought it requisite to make a Resignation of all their Right and Title to the Crown, saving however to themselves the Rights of the Empire; in Pur∣suance of which Resolution, and Renunciation, they declar'd and acknowledg'd the said Arch-duke to be King of Spain. After the Empe∣ror had concluded, the Chancellor of the Court read both the Acts of Renunciation, as well in Behalf of his Imperial Majesty, as of the King of the Romans; as also another Act on the Behalf of the Arch-duke, containing, as some say, his Acceptance of the Spanish Crown, and a relinquishing of all his Right and Claim to the Dominions of the House of Austria in the Empire. Which done, the Emperor, and the King of the Romans, re∣pair'd to an Altar, erected at the End of the
Room, where they swore to the Religious Ob∣servance of the Conditions and Stipulations of the said Act, as did also the Arch-duke for his Part, the Gospels being presented to their Majesty's by Cardinal Colonitz.
Here it is acknowledged, that this was done at the Instance of Her Majesty of Great-Britain, and the King of Portugal, the latter was influenced by the Almirant de Castile, as above.

And to give a Testimony of the early Obligations of this Prince to Her Majesty, here follows the Translation of a Letter, written by the Emperor Leopold with his own Hand to Her Majesty, recommend∣ing the New King to Her, as to his Mo∣ther, acknowledging the Great Instrument Her Majesty had been in procuring that Honour to his Son, and expressing what none indeed for ever after could doubt but would be found, in a Person of true Ho∣nour; (viz.) a lasting Obligation of Thank∣fulness and Gratitude: We shall make no Comment hereupon, the Thing speaks itself; the Letter follows thus.

DIV2.HEAD: A Letter from the Emperor to Her Majesty.

LETTER.HEAD: Leopoldus, Imp. Semp. Aug. &c.
LETTER.P:
ACcording to our Mutual Friendship, we do, by these Presents, signifie to your Serenity, with a Friendly Affection, and in a Brotherly Manner, that Yesterday, with the Consent of our First-born Son, the King of the Romans, we conferr'd upon our other Son, the Arch-duke of Austria Charles the Third, the Spanish Monarchy, legally de∣volv'd upon us by the Death of the Illustrious Catholick King Charles the Second, and did openly declare him King of Spain and the Indies, under God's Gracious Protection. This Matter has been long deliberated by us, and could not easily be adjusted, because many Things offered themselves to our Consideration Pro and Con; but while we were in Suspence, the Judgment and Advice of your Serenity, signify'd to us by your Envoy Extraordinary, was of great Weight to remove our Doubts; and being mov'd in your Serenities Name to hasten this Declaration, and the Departure of our said Son, we did the more readily and willingly undertake it, because we have al∣ways found in your Serenity a great Foresight in giving and receiving Council, and a Faith∣ful
Performance of your Promises. We have also observed in your Serenity such a particu∣lar Affection and Good-will towards us and our House of Austria, that we firmly believe your Serenity will not only take what we have done in good Part, but will always regard it as your own Act. Our said Son would gladly sig∣nifie this to your Serenity, and express our Joint Gratitude and Acknowledgment of it in Person; but since the present Posture of the Common Affairs calls him further, he will perform this in another Method at his Arri∣val. But may it please your Serenity in the mean Time to allow us, since he is to leave us in a few Days, wholly to deliver him over, and to recommend him to your Serenity as to an∣other Mother, with Assurance on his Part, that as long as he lives he shall honour your Sereni∣ty with Filial Respect; and that our Family shall ever be oblig'd to serve your Serenity in the strictest Manner, and in perpetual Grati∣tude. We add no more, but our Prayers to the Almighty and Gracious God to grant your Serenity long Health, and Happy Success.

DIV2.P: Immediately upon the Declaration and Letter abovesaid, the Young King is sent by Land from Vienna to Holland, and passing from thence to England, we find him re∣ceiv'd by Her Majesty with all that Good∣ness and Bounty that suited the first Steps taken for his Advancement.

All this while it may not be amiss to note, and it seems most proper to come in here, that his Young Majesty not only owed his Access to the Spanish Monarchy, to the Good-will, and particular Assistance of Her Britannick Majesty, but even all the Title and Pretence he could make to the Crown, has also its Rise in Her Maje∣sty since nothing is more notorious, than that he had no Claim of Blood to that Crown, his Father, and his Elder Brother being both at that Time alive: But as one very happily Remarks on that Subject, he had no other Title to Claim by, but what made the Title of his Rival stronger than his own. We are loth to mingle this Account with Quotations from other Authors, but the Argument brought to prove this, is thus abridged.

Philip of Bourbon, had no Right to the Crown by Descent, because, tho' the Renun∣ciation of the Treaty at the Pyrennees had been of no Force, his Father, and Elder Brother, (viz.) the Dauphine, and the Duke of Burgundy, were both Living, and the Title, if any, was theirs before him.

Charles of Austria had no Right to the Crown by Descent, because, tho' Philip's Claim had been of no Force, yet his Father, and his Elder Brother, (viz.) the Emperor Leopold, and the King of Hungaria, were both Living, and the Right was theirs be∣fore him.
Philip Claims by Gift from Charles II. deceased.
Charles Claims by Gift from the Empe∣ror his Father, and King of Hungaria, his Brother.

The Emperor says Crowns are not giv∣en like Gloves, and Gold Rings, at Fune∣rals; nor does a Right to Govern the Sub∣jects of Spain descend by Will and Assigna∣tion, but by Right of Blood, and Lineal Descent; and therefore Charles II. of Spain, could not demise his Dominions to Philip.

Philip says, if a Gift is not good, neither has Charles any Right more than he, who derives only from the Gift and Resignation of Leopold and Joseph, his Father, and El∣der Brother, who had no more Right to give it away, than Charles II.
We say it seems undeniable thus.
That if a Gift of the Possessor is not va∣lid, neither of these Princes can make any Claim at all.
But if a Gift is Valid, then Philip has the best Title, because his Gift was prior to the other.
There is an Additional Claim, which either Parties lay respectively to this Monar∣chy, (viz.) that of the Sword; which indeed seems to be the best Right either of them have to the Claim.

We must indeed own a new Right since these descended to both, (1.) To King
Charles, in that this Father, and Elder Brother, are both dead without other Issue Male. (2.) To King Philip, (viz.) that his Father be∣ing dead, there remains no Successor but the Duke of Burgundy, who being to succeed to the Crown of France, is not thought of: And Possession, a Title, which if then he can keep, it will be worth all the rest.

But to return to the Behaviour of this King Sine-Ter, in the Introduction to his New Dominion; where it should be noted, the Intent is not here to lessen his Catho∣lick Majesty, as if he had misbehaved; on the contrary, it is certain he did all that a Prince could decently stoop to do, to let Her Majesty know, that he knew how to acknowledge the Obligation he was under; and to let the World see, it was a King paying all that just Respect to Her that made him so, which a Prince full of Gratitude, and who understood both himself, and the Favour he had receiv'd, ought to pay.

For this, take the short View of his Beha∣viour at Windsor, where he arriv'd 26 De∣cember, 1703, Her Majesty receiv'd him at the head of the Stairs, where his first Bow to Her Majesty seem'd by all that saw it, to signifie, that he meant to kiss the Ground at Her Feet; there he made Her Majesty a very becoming Compliment, acknowledging his great Obligations to her, &c.

We are the more willing to set down these Particulars, tho' they may seem tri∣fling, because they are thus far to the Case in hand, as they signifie the Just Sence his Majesty had then upon his Mind of his In∣finite Engagements to the Generosity and Kindness of the Queen.

Let us now follow his Majesty into his own Dominions, and there we shall find him, not only generously on all Oc∣casions acknowledging Her Majesties Goodness and Bounty, as to obtaining for him the Crown of Spain; but often reduc'd even to entreat and sollicit her Majesty, not only to support him in his Possession, but to rescue him from his Enemies, who had besieged him in the only City of which he was possess'd in the World; and where, but for Her Majesties Seasonable and Pow∣erful Succours, he had inevitably fallen into the Hands of his Enemies.

Here we find him so long confin'd, so low reduc'd, and so like to be ruined, that the French at Madrid in Derision call'd him Il poco Rey de Barcelone, the little King of Bar∣celona; and even after this Deliverance there we have him reduc'd so low, as not to have even ad for his Houshold, or as we may say, Shoes to his Feet, but from her Maje∣sties Bounty: As these Things ought not to be said of a Person now in the most Supreme Degree of Human Dignity in the Christian World, without such Evidence of Fact, as
admits no Dispute; so we shall admit no E∣vidence to be sufficient, of Less Dignity than himself, having his own Hand-writing to show for every Thing as we go along, which we hope will be allow'd to be the best Kind of Testimony.

But to take Things in Order: Assoon as his Catholick Majesty, (so we must now call him,) came to Lisbon; among the rest of the Ceremonies paid to him there, Mr. Methuen, the Queen's Ambassador to the King of Portugal, sent his Son on Board the Men of War to Compliment his Majesty on his Arrival; his Majesty received him very graciously, and express'd in the most obliging Terms, the great Respect and Vene∣ration he hath for Her Majesty, and how sensi∣ble he is of the great and many Obligations he oweth Her, which he hopeth he should be so Hap∣py as to be able to return in such a Manner as might shew the whole World the grateful Sence he should always retain of Her Majesties Kind∣ness to him. The Envoy himself, who was in∣dispos'd before, had Audience of his Majesty afterwards, to Compliment him upon his safe coming on Shore, to whom again his Ca∣tholick Majesty expressed the great Respect he had for Her Majesty, and how much he thought himself obliged to Her.
Here we may leave K. Charles a while, and go back to the Conduct of Her Majesty to the Emperor, his Father; and this may be confin'd to Two Cases.

1. The March of the Duke of Marlbo∣rough into Germany with the Confederate Army the Beginning of the Year 1704, which ended in the great Victory at Hocksted, which Victory visibly delivered the Empire from Destruction, and set his Imperial Ma∣jesty free from the Invasion of the Duke of Bavaria, who, as it was evident by the Steps he had already taken, would, in less than Two Months, have been at the Gates of Vienna.

This, that it may not be thought asumed, we shall give from like Authority, for there is no Proof like the Acknowledgment of Parties; indeed the History of the Duke of Marlborough's March, of the Original, the Measures concerted for it, &c. but above all, the Expence for it, of which 600000 l. was out of the English Treasury, would confirm it; but the Emperor's Letter to the States of Holland, and to the Duke of Marlborough, who, upon that Occasion, he made a Prince of the Empire, leave it past all Contradiction; both what his Condition was be∣fore the Battle, and what was Effected by it.

LETTER.HEAD: Leopoldus, &c.
Illustrissime Charissime Consanguinee & Princeps, &c.
LETTER.P: EXtare nimitum etiam hoc volui maximi in Germania Honoris a me in vos merito collati publicum Monumentum, quo magis omnibus pateat quantum cum Serenissimae Mag∣nae Britaniae Reginae, quod rebus meis & Im∣perii ob perfidam Bavari ad Gallum defectio∣nem non liviter concessis, eximias suppetias in Vindeliciam & Bavariam usque sub ductu vestro miserit, tum dilectioni vestrae me & Imperium debere ultro agnoscam, quod tam prudenter, tam fortiter, tam prospere res gestae sunt; cum non fama sola, sed meae quo∣que Militiae supremi, laborum vestrorum & Victoriatum Socii & Participes, eas vestris imprimis consiliis & virtuti Anglicarumque, & aliarum copiarum sub directione vestra Militantium fortitudini acceptas referant.

CLOSER.DATELINE: Dabantur in urbe mea Viennae 28 Augusti, 1704.

DIV2.P: The Letter of the same Emperor to the States of Holland, upon the same Occasion of the Battle of Hochsted, expresses suffici∣ently the Condition the Affairs of the Em∣pire were in, and how this Action had de∣livered them, to which also we refer the Rea∣der, as Printed in our Gazette.
The Aforesaid Letter, to his Grace the Duke of Marlborough, is in English thus:

OPENER.SALUTE: Most Illustrious Cousin, and Dear Prince,

LETTER.P: I Have been willing that this Publick Monu∣ment of the Supream Honour in Germany, which I have so deservedly conferred upon you, should remain, that it may more and more ap∣pear to all the World, how much, as I freely own it, I, and all the Empire, owe to the most Serene Queen of Great-Britain, for having sent Her Powerful Assistances as far as Augs∣burg, and Bavaria itself, under your Conduct; when my own Affairs, and those of the Empire, were so much shaken and disordered by the per∣fidious Defection of the Bavarian to the French, and also to your Dilection, upon Ac∣count that Things have been so prudently, so vigorously, and successfully, transacted; for not only Fame, but also the Generals of my Forces, the Companions aud Sharers of your Labours and Victories, attribute the same chiefly to your Councils, and the Valour and Bravery of the English, and other Forces who fought under your Conduct.

CLOSER.DATELINE: Given in my City of Vienna August 28, 1704.

DIV2.P:
The Second Action to oblige and serve the Emperor, we need go no arther for than the Loan of 200000 l. Sterling, bor∣row'd for him on the remote Fund of hi
Taxes in Silesia; and this was raised by Subscription in the City of London, at a Time when the Funds in England, for our own Occasions, required exceeding large Sums to be raised; yet even in this Her Ma∣jesty used her Interest for the Emperor, and recommending it to Her Subjects, the Money was raised with great Chearfulness, great Part where of is unpaid to this Day.

But as it is not the Business of this Tract to dwell upon Matters, or add any Thing by Way of Exaggeration, to the Engage∣ments the House of Austria lye under to the Queen, the bare History of Fact being suf∣ficient, so we proceed to the many Branches yet behind, relating more especially to the King of Spain, now Emperor.

We are now to follow the said King of Spain from Lisbon to Barcelona, where he arri∣ved about the Beginning of September, 1705, the taking of Barcelona and Gironne, Lerida and Tortosa, and settling him on a power∣ful Interest, in the Possession of the Prin∣cipality of Catalonia, is not the present Bu∣siness; for we are not upon the History of what Her Majesty has done for him; but upon the Relation of his own grateful Sense of it, and therefore shall only give you a Fragment of a long Letter from his Catholick Majesty to the Queen, dated in Barcelona, when the Remembrance of the Obligation was warm in his Mind; the whole Letter is full of the like Acknow∣ledgment;
but being Joth to tire the Rea∣der, we content ourselves with this Part for want of Room.

LETTER.P:
NOthing remains, but that I return you my most respectful Thanks for having sent me so great a Fleet, and so Good and Valiant Troops to assist me. After such Happy Begin∣nings, I thought it proper, according to the Opinion of your Generals, and Admirals, to maintain in Person the Conquest we have made, and to shew my Subjects, who are so Affectionate to my Person, that I cannot abandon them. I receive so great an Assistance from your Ma∣jesty, and your Generous Nation, that I am overcome with your Goodness; and in the greatest Confusion, that I should be the Occa∣sion of so great an Expence for the supporting my Interest: But, Madam, I give up my own Person, and my Subjects in Catalonia, who expose their Lives and Fortunes upon the As∣surances they have of your Generous Protection. Your Majesty, and your Council, know better than we what is necessary for our Preservation. We shall wait for your Majesty's Succours, with an entire Confidence in your Goodness and Wisdom. It may be seen what Forces are ne∣cessary; it may also be seen how great a Diver∣sion we shall give to France; it cannot be doubted but that they will make their utmost Efforts against me as soon as possible, and I doubt not but the same Efforts will be used by my Allies to defend me. What can be said to you, Madam? Your Goodness gives you the
Inclination, and your Power furnishes you with the Means to support those whom the Ty∣ranny of France would oppress. All that I can suggest to your Wisdom, and to that of your Allies, is, that the Forces employ'd in this Country will not remain useless to the Publick Good, but will be under an Obligation, and a Necessity to act with the utmost Vigour against the Enemy. I am ever, with the most Sincere Affection, Respect, and Gratitude.

CLOSER.SALUTE: MADAM, MY Sister, Your most Affectionate Brother,
CLOSER.DATELINE: From the Camp at Senia before Barcelona, Octo∣ber 22, 1705.

DIV2.P: None can say but his Catholick Majesty expresses himself here like a Man of Ho∣nour; and like a Prince, that had on his Mind deep Impressious of what has been done for him; and indeed all his Letters seem to signifie, that his Majesty thought he could never enough extol Her Majesties Goodness to him, but shall see g ater Occasion still, for him both to want, and to acknowledge the Queen of Great-Britain.

We left him set safe on Shore in his Principality of Catalonia, and the Cy of Barcelona taken for him by the Ea of
Peterborough, which he acknowledged to the Generous Assistance of the Queen, in his Letter already quoted, as before. But we soon find him, not only threatned in his New Possession, but greatly Streightned by the Approach of his Enemies on Two Sides, (viz.) the Duke de Noailles on the Side of Rousillon, and his Rival King Philip, on the Side of Arragon, with Two several Armies; we find him reduced to great Streights, even to the besieging him in his Capital of Bar∣celona, and there bringing him even to the very Brink of falling into the Enemies Hands in Person. This Distress both himself, and his Ministers, are far from being in the least backward to acknowledge, in the many pressing Instances made to Her Majesties Court, Generals, and Admirals, for Relief; as well as in his Acknowledgments, when de∣livered. It cannot but be very proper to see the Language of both to hear the Complaints and Vows of this Prince, in his Distress, that we may the better compare it with the Language he is pleased to use since that, to the same Prince, who then so generously, vigorously, and successfully, supported and delivered him.

LETTER.HEAD: LETTER from King Charles to Sir J—L—.
I the KING.
LETTER.P: I Am disposed to take upon me this Occasion to advise you of the high Risk this Princi∣pality, and my Royal Person, is found in; for I make no doubt e'er the Morrow the Ene∣my will molest us; they have already blockad∣ed me with a Squadron of Ships, and their Army is now almost in Sight of this City, and by their quick Marches have obtained some Posts, which if they might have been prevent∣ed would very much have hindered their Designs.

I am resolved, (altho' I find myself with such a small Garrison as 1000 Men of Regu∣lar Troops, and 400 Horse,) not to leave this Place, for in the present Conjuncture I have considered that my going hence will be the Loss of the City, and consequently of all the other Places, which the happy Success of the last Campaign hath reduced to my Obedi∣ence; for which Reason it is my Opinion to risk all, and venture the Casualties that a Siege is incident to, putting Trust and Con∣fidence in your known Zeal toward the great forwarding the Common Cause, making no
doubt how much you have contributed towards the Succours Forwardness. I hope in a few Days you will appear before this Place, where your known Valour and Activity may meet with a Glorious Success, for which I shall again constitutē you the Credit of my Royal Gratitude.

CLOSER.DATELINE: Given in Barcelona the 31st of March, 1706.
CLOSER.SALUTE: I the KING, By the Command of the King my Master,

DIV2.P: But impatient lest this Letter should miscarry, and the Danger encreasing, he sends another, written by his Chief Mini∣ster, the Prince of Lichtenstein, to press for Succour, in which his Danger is still more passionately set out, as follows.

LETTER.HEAD: The Prince of Lichtenstein's Letter to Sir J—L—.
LETTER.P:
FEaring the Letter his Catholick Majesty sent you some Days since came not to your Hands, he ordered me to send you a Copy thereof, and to advertise you of the great Danger he finds the City of Barcelona, and his Royal Person to be in, the Enemy about
14000 in Number, not being above Three or Four Leagues distant from hence, on a di∣rect March to besiege this City, before which there appeared the Day before Yesterday about 50 Tartans, and small Vessels, to join 17 Men of War, which are here at Anchor, which being added to these already on the Coast, will make 25 Sail for the Line. We are im∣patiently expecting you here, which will be the only Means to secure this City, and his Maje∣sties Sacred Person, from the Danger he is in. The Passes being all cut off, we can ex∣pect no Relief any other Way; I beg of you, in the Name of God, to come to our Relief as soon as possible with what Ships and Troops at this Instant you have at Hand, the Danger of losing Catalonia, and the Preservation of his Majesties Person, which is of so great Consequence to all Christendom, will not admit of any farther Delays in Expectation of the Irish Forces, which are design'd for Lis∣bon, and may follow your Squadron without any Manner of Danger. His Majesty sa∣lutes you very heartily, and assures you he will not forget your Diligence; and I hope, in a short Time, to have the Honour of seeing you. I am very sincerely your Affectionate, &c.

DIV2.P: One other Letter, tho' written before the last, is needful to prove, that the whole Dependence of the King was on Her Ma∣jesties Help, and that without Her, all they had gained in Catalonia must have been lost.

LETTER.HEAD: Copy of Prince Lichtenstein's Letter of the same Date.
LETTER.P:
HIS Majesty the King, my Master, finds at this Conjuncture the Principality attacked on both Sides by the Enemies conside∣rable Armies, one whereof is under the Com∣mand of the Duke of Anjou, and the other the Duke of Noailles, and the City of Bar∣celona like to be besieged; you may easily judge of the great Necessity there is to assist us speedily with the Squadron, Troops, and Money, which the Queen, your Mistress, has designed to∣wards the succouring of Catalonia. All the Ad∣vices we have of the Designs and Motions of the Enemy agree, that they resolve to leave the Towns of Lerida and Girone behind them, and to march with all their Forces directly for Barcelona; which Place, in the Condition it is in at present, is able to make but a very weak Defence, having no Regular Troops, and only guarded by its Inhabitants. And the Fort of Montjuic is found in the same Condition as when it was taken, the City being also without Stores, Provisions, and
Money. I well know his Majesty is confident of your Zeal and Application for his Royal Ser∣vice, and the Common Cause, that you will use all possible Diligence to come hither with the Troops that are to be Landed, without any Delay or Hindrance, without which this City, and all the Principality of Catalonia, which depends on its Preservation, will run the Risk of being lost, with as much Ease, and in as little Time, as the Glorious Arms of the Queen, your Mistress, joined with those of the Lords, the States General, conquered it: Be∣sides, the Sacred Person of his Majesty will be exposed to inevitable Dangers, waiting the Honour of saluting you in a very short Time.

POSTSCRIPT.P: P. S. Eight of the Enemies Ships have Weighed, and are Anchored again nearer this City, which makes me more pressing that you will come speedily with your Squadron and Forces.

DIV2.P:
I shall finish this doleful Relation by one Letter more under King Charles's own Hand, to Admiral Leake, when he was just as it were ready to be devoured by his Enemies, and as it were, to be taken by Storm; and indeed it was far from being a Jest, for the French had infallibly storm'd the Place the next Day; nor was there any possible Method for him to propose an Escape, all the Choice left him was to be carried in Triumph to
Madrid, or to die in the Breach. Let any Man read the Letter, and he will judge whether we carry it too far.

LETTER.HEAD: A Translation of King Charles's Let∣ter to Sir J—L—.
LETTER.P: `TIS with no small Satisfaction that I have been informed from the Earl of P—gh's Letters of your happy Arrival upon the Coast of Valencia; I doubt not but you have heard of the Loss of Montjuic, and of the Condition my Town of Barcelona is in, where I was willing to suffer myself to be be∣sieged, and to endure all the Hardships, and the Accidents of War, to encourage both the Garrison and my Subjects, by my Presence, to make a Long and Vigorous Defence.

It seems, by the Enemies Motions, they have already received Notice of your Approach, but instead of thinking to retreat, they have redoubled their Efforts, and fire upon the Breach, which will be in a Condition to be stormed after to Morrow at farthest, and in all Appearance they will make a desperate At∣tempt to render themselves Masters of this Town before the Fleet can arrive with the Suc∣cours.

Hence you will judge of the indispensible Necessity there is that you do your utmost Endeavours, using all possible Diligence to re∣lieve us without Loss of Time, and bring the Fleet directly hither, together with the Troops, to my Town of Barcelona, which is at the very Point of being lost for want of Relief. Wherefore I pray God to have you in his Holy Protection, and expecting the Pleasure of see∣ing you as soon as possible, I assure you of my perfect Esteem and Acknowledgment.

POSTSCRIPT.P: P. S. Sir, you will see the Condition we are in by our Letters, and I hope you will come as soon as possible to save us, of which you alone shall have the Glory. For the rest I refer you to Mr. St.—pe's Letter.

DIV2.P:
Thus far the Distresses of this Prince are at large expressed under his own Hand, and those of his Servants, for he is very remarkable for being full of Letters; we could fill a great Part of this Tract with his Letters to the Queen, to the States-Gene∣ral, to the Duke of Marlborough, and se∣veral others, upon the happy Deliverance which was wrought for him by the Eng∣lish Succours, but we spare the Reader that Trouble for want of Room; every one knows that Barcelona was relieved by
Sir John Leake, and Sir George Bing; it shall suffice to note, that it was done at such a Crisis of Time, that the Fleet was no sooner in the Road, but the King sent on Board to desire that some of the For∣ces might immediately Land, lest the Town might be lost while they were look∣ing on, for that they expected the Enemy would storm the Breach that very Night.

But the Obligations his Catholick Maje∣sty has to the Queen of Great-Britain are not yet at an End, and we must follow the farther Course of his Reign through several Vi∣cissitudes of Fortune. The Current of his Good Success carried him a great Way at this Time; he saw his Rival fled, himself surrounded with a gallant Body of British and Dutch Troops, Catalonia all his own, part of Valencia possessed, and some of Arragon; but this not all; immediately News comes to him, that the Earl of Gall∣way, with another English Army in Con∣junction with the Portugueze, had march∣ed into the Heart of Spain, and had taken the Capital, the Royal Palace and City of Madrid, and he had nothing to do but to go and take Possession. What Difficulty, Disa∣greement, Loss and Disappointment follow∣ed, which lost him all these happy Steps a∣gain, serve only to convince the World that he had no Support, no Supply, no, not A SHOE to his Foot, or Bread to eat, bu by the Bounty and Generous Hand of He
Britannick Majesty, and this is the true De∣sign of these Sheets.

The marching to Madrid was of the ut∣most Consequence, and great Strife and Contention there was among the Generals, the Earl of Gallway, Lord Peterborow, and others; one why he did not come this Way, the other why he did not come that Way. But Count Gallas, the Emperor's Envoy, cleared up the Point, (viz.) that the E—of P—having not supplied his Poor Majesty with Money, as he said he should have done, and he having no other Way in the World to get any, truly he could not stir at all. We have nothing to do with the Quarrel among them at that Time, or to enquire who were, or were not, to blame, the Case seems to be most exactly Stated and Discovered to the World in a late Book, Entituled, “”An Impartial Enquiry into the Management of the War in Spain, by the Ministry at Home, and into the Conduct of those Generals, to whose Care the same has been committed Abroad; collected from many Original Letters, and Councils of War, never pub∣lished before.

Where all the Original Papers on either Side are at large recorded, and where, who∣ever thinks fit to enquire, may see some∣thing of a different Account from what most Men have entertained of that Affair. This is to our Purpose, and for this Reason we
mention the Matter, that Count Gallas in the said Memorial, to be seen also in the said Book, p▪ 153, acquaints Her Majesty of the true Reason why King Charles did not go faster on to Madrid, in these Words: “”His Catholick Majesty having from his first coming into that Country, till that Time, received no more from the said Lord than once 10000 Crowns to mount the Regiment of Zinzendorf, 15000 Pistoles at another Time for the Expence of the Siege of Barcelona, and 5000 Dou∣bloons for the Fortifications of Gironne; and being obliged to provide himself all that was necessary in this unhappy Con∣juncture, saw himself reduced to so des∣perate a Condition, that Far from being able to do what was resolved on, (viz.) to march to Madrid by the Way of Valencia, he wanted even what was necessary for the daily supplying his own Table; and found himself so loaded with Debts, that he had Reason to apprehend some Disorders would ensue, if he should depart without paying them.

This is a lively Representation of the Condition of this now so Glorious Monarch, who refuses to treat with the French at Her Majesties Invitation. But this is not all, let us go on, and see in what Humble Man∣ner he lays his Case at Her Majesties Feet, and implores Her Assistance; you have it in
the same Memorial of the Count Gallas, just at the close, in the following Words.

P.Q: “”And as your Majesty will perceive by this Account, that his Catholick Majesties Condition, for want of Means, is brought to this, that he is in Danger every Mo∣ment of seeing himself abandoned not on∣ly by his Troops, but even by the very Servants of his own Houshold, who for this Year and Half have not received the least Payment, which cannot happen with∣out rendering his Royal Person contempti∣ble to the Spaniards, and without his losing the Affection and Respect of those, who hitherto have been the best and fastest Friends, discouraging those whom he farther hoped to bring over to his Interest, and giving the Enemy all the Advantage they can desire.

“”His Catholick Majesty therefore flatters himself, that after so many Favours granted him by your Majesty, you will not suffer him to sink under his Misfortunes, but will forthwith assist him with Money, to preserve him from all those Extremities, wherewith both his Person, and the Common Cause of all the Allies are threatned.

DIV2.P:
We have now brought the Emperor to his first Journey to Madrid the latter End of the Year 1707 being a few Months before the Battle of Almanza, his Dependance on Her Majesty in all his Distresses, his being
frequently relieved and supported, and indeed constantly, whenever he was in any Exigence, by Her Majesties Assistance, and his having no other Help; these are all so clear that we cannot believe his Majesty will forbear to acknowledge it at any Time.

We might trace him through all the Sub∣sequent Variety of his Fortunes, as the Battle of Almanza, the Success at Balaguer, at arragossa, and his Second March to Madrid, and his Retreat again after the Affair of Briheuga and might swell this little Tract to a great Volume with his own repeated Sollicitations to the Queen for Help, and Acknowledgments when re∣ceiv'd; but the last mention'd may suffice.

We must now salute him Emperor; what Influence Her Majesty and Her Allies have had in his Advancement, he has not yet indeed given us many Verbal Acknow∣ledgments of, at least that are made Pub∣lick; perhaps we may live to see them farther demonstrated in a little Time.

In the mean Time, the Expence Her Majesty and Her People have been at to support this Prince merit some Considera∣tion in the World, and may not very im∣properly be summ'd up to form this Ac∣count, especially since we are not so much stating an Account of Debtor and Creditor as to Money, but a Debt of Gratitude, and Ingratitude, in which the Money disburst, the Blood and Lives lost, in his Quarrel, and
Services done for his Person, stand on the one Side to his Debt in Account, and his Acknow∣ledgments are the Vouchers to prove that Account. The Return, the Behaviour, the Compliance with Things reasonable, &c. are the Credit Part, or Discharge, of the Account, and we shall soon see how they Ballance.

Nor is it any Plea in Bar of this Demand, to say that we carried on the General Quar∣rel of the Confederacy, or that the War was not undertaken on his Account; for tho' that may be true in General, yet as to that Part of it carried on in Catalonia, and with or about his Person, this cannot be denied to be carried on meerly to serve, oblige, promote, and support, him in parti∣cular, and none else.

How Fruitless the Success, how Ex∣pensive the Particular Service, and how Unhappy to Britain, and to all the Confe∣deracy, that War has been; how much more to our Advantage it had been, that the Expence on that Side had been employ'd either in America, Italy, or Flanders; these Things, tho' all of them very well worth enquiring into, on many other Accounts, yet, as they are not to be plac'd directly to his Account, we purposely omit; but as to the Account above let us enquire a little into the Particulars, and a long Account indeed we shall find it; enough to make any Prince in the World remember the Ob∣ligation
as long as he liv'd; an Account of Treasure and Blood, which no Nation but ours perhaps could have disburst for him, and which, to be sure, none but ours would have done in the Manner we have, without any Article or Condition of Repay∣ment or Satisfaction.

And this is a Clause deserves several Kinds of Observation. Well may King Charles, and the Emperor, his Father, call Her Majesty Mother; for the Treatment he has receiv'd from hence has gone beyond even the manner of Fathers in this Age; the King of France has not acted thus even with his own Flesh and Blood, for he has stopped the Treasure of his Grandson's Galleons more than once, and repaid himself out of them, for the vast Stores of Ammunition, and Arms, and the Payment of Troops, sent to his Assistance; nay, and if the Returns by their Merchants Ships from the South-Seas may be reckoned, some say he has been over-paid too: But England has acted upon another Foot, meer Care and Concern, truly Maternal, seeking no Reward, articling for no Return, taking no Pledge or Security for Repayment. Her Britannick Majesty might have asked the Possession of such Places as should be taken by Her Arms; such as Barcelona, Gi∣braltar, Port Mahon, or even Naples, Mi∣lan, or the like, to be consign'd over to Her for Payment, when the King should
e settled in his Dominions by Her Assistance. She might have Capitulated for Cadiz, or the Havana, or such other Places, as might have been very much the Advantage of Her People, to hold till the immense Sums should be repaid, which were An∣nually disburs'd for his Service. Nor were we so Rich, or so little in Debt to our Mortgaged Funds, that Ten Millions of Bullion in Specie, after the End of the War, would not have been both very useful, and very acceptable to us, to restore our Com∣merce, and recover our Nation, and help lighten the Burthen which these Things have fastened upon the Shoulders of our Posterity for so many Ages to come.

But all these Considerations have been of no Weight with us; the Assistance received from hence has been so generous, so free, as not to give the least Room to say we have imposed the least Conditions upon him; Her Majesty has acted with such Frank∣ness, all has been done with a Paternal Concern for him, neither Capitulating for, or expecting any Payment; all that can be said we ever Conditioned for was that Clause in the VIth Article of the Grand Al∣liance, wherein it is said, It shall be lawful for his Royal Majesty of Great-Britain, and the Lords the States-General, by common Ad∣vice, and for the Benefit and Enlargement of the Navigation and Commerce of their Subjects, to seize by their Forces what Lands and Ci∣ties
they can, belonging to the Spanish Domi∣nions in the Indies; and whatsoever they so take shall be their own.

In it appears we are to have nothing till we can get it for ourselves, and even that, it seems they never proposed we should do, especially if it be true which an Au∣thor lately Published, that when our Ex∣pedition was fitting out to the River of St. Laurence, and that it was suggested to the last Emperor that we were going to the Spanish West-Indies, his Imperial Majesty should say, “”Sure the English could not be so Insolent. If this be true, (which however probable, yet we will not affirm,) it would but too clearly discover the Temper of the German Court to be far enough from the Gratitude which some People think them∣selves secure of.

But that this seeming Demand of Grati∣tude may not appear so unreasonable, it may not be improper to state a little, not what Britain may expect, but what Britain has done; let others judge what we ought, to expect, and what a Return Gratitude ought to make to a Nation, that has gone such a Length for them, and indeed the Sum in general is so great, that unless the Parti∣culars are a little set down, Posterity will think the Authors hereof spoke by Guess, and that it was impossible any Thing like it could be true.

Wherefore the following Account is set down, that his Imperial Majesty, if he pleases, or any one for him, may Revise, and look back upon the few small Matters that have been done for him, and the tri∣fling Assistance which this Single Nation has given him towards establishing him on the Spanish Throne.

And first, for Troops sent to his Assi∣stance, the Expence whereof is such, that as it has been represented to the Parliament; and as it is to be demonstrated in the Au∣thor above recited, in his Book, The Impar∣tial Enquiry, &c. every Foot Soldier cost the English Nation, before he was set on Shore in Spain, 26 l. 6 s. 10 d. per Head Sterling, an Expence which would have made a loud Noise in other Countries, and which perhaps few even in this Country will believe till they have read the Parti∣culars.

'Tis an Unhappy Reflection for this Poor Nation to think, that of above Sixty-five Thousand Englishmen in particular sent to Spain for the assisting this Grateful Prince, not many above the odd Five Thousand are remaining alive at this Time, and how few of them may be likely to see their own Nation again Time may shew us.

Besides, into this Number are not reckon∣ed the Seamen or Marines lost or dead on board the Fleet in this Service: Nor is there reckoned into this any of the Charge
of the Navy, which yearly amounts to above Two Millions, and most of which is employed in the Service of the King o Spain, even in so Servile a Manner, that our Men of War have been turn'd into meer Transports and Storeships for his Service; a Work we never let them be em∣ployed in at home: But the King's Necessi∣ties urging, so Zealous has Her Majesty and her Officers been to put forward his Catholick Majesties Service, that they have stuck at nothing, nor made Difficulties, even of Things they are not allowed at other Times to do.
