DIV2.P: We could hardly expect these Heads to be received by those who have only enter∣tain'd Common Notions of these Things, and were not the Particulars to be proved and confirm'd by proper Vouchers, as well in the Publick Offices where the Accounts are kept respectively, as in the General Ab∣stracts laid before the Parliament, we should not have presumed to have inserted them here.
We are now to put a Stop to the long Account, tho' England is not yet happily at a Stop of the Expence, either of Men or Money.

One would think that his Catholick Majesty being now upon higher Terms with his Al∣lies, and being busie, telling the World what great Efforts he will make against the Com∣mon Enemy, what Powerful Armies he will bring into the Field, and the like, it would have been very Grateful, Honoura∣ble, and perhaps but Reasonable, that he would write One Letter more to Her Ma∣jesty, and after a due Acknowledgment of the great Things done for him, and the great Assistance She has given, as well to maintain him in Catalonia, as to influence his Election to the Emperor, to assure Her Majesty he will think now of some Means to repay, or secure, at the End of the War, the Repayment of those immense Sums She has laid out to assist him; and that to save the Expence of the Blood of Her Subjects
he will now pursue the War in Spain at his own Expence, and with his own Troops; and that if Her Majesty pleases to cause Her Fleet to attend for some Time the necessary Service, as aforesaid, His Majesty will also pay Her the Charge thereof, to be adjusted as they shall agree.

This would be something considerable; and from such a Thing as this in the Be∣ginning; we might hope for greater Things in the End; and above all, any One would think that at a Treaty of Peace, whenever that should be, none should be so forward as his Catholick Majesty to see Her Britannick Majesty receive suitable Amends and Satisfaction for all these Migh∣ty Things done, and Assistance lent him.

But instead of this, let us look a little into his Conduct, and see what Tendency it has to such Things, and what Appearance of the very Temper of Gratitude there is in those Things he has done, or in what he proposes to himself to do: In the making these Observations we shall treat his Majesty with all that Courtesie and Decency which the Dignity of his Person and Character Com∣mands from Men of Honour, only preserv∣ing that Duty always owing to Truth, which we can by no Means dispence with.

As soon as the News came to these Parts of the Death of the late Emperor Joseph, the States-General, who received that News in Course some Time before us, met, and
in concert with Her Majesties Envoy at the Hague, took Vigorous and Timely Reso∣lutions for advancing and espousing the Interest of King Charles III. in the Ensuing Election of an Emperor. These Resoluti∣ons were immediately approved, seconded, and confirm'd, by Her Majesty, and Let∣ters, Envoys, Missions and Exhortations, were dispatch'd immediately by the said States-General and the British Court to all the Electors, Princes of the Empire, and others concerned, to press them to adhere to the Interest of King Charles, and to unite their Votes and their Forces also: For that End, the Troops appointed to form an Army on the Oder, for preserving the Peace of the Empire, commonly known by the Name of the Army of the Neutrality, were ordered to march from Silesia, and to draw down towards the Rhine, to support the Election; and such Effectual Measures were taken on this Occasion by the English and Dutch, that all the Steps concerted by the French to disturb the said Election by Force, as well as all the Intrigues of the Pope, who sent his Nephew Don Annibal Albani to Frankfort for that Purpose, could not in the least prove Effectual; nor could they prevail to obtain the Admission of the ex∣cluded Electors of Bavaria and Cologne, or to have their Vote receiv'd in the Electoral College.

At the same Time, to assure and encou∣rage the Young Prince himself, a Letter was immediately dispatch'd to him by an Express, in the Name of the States-Gene∣neral, but Countersign'd, as approved by the English Embassador there; wherein are so great Expressions of Kindness, Concern, Affection, and Faithful adhering to his In∣terest, as it would be a severe Satyr on his Majesty to say or suggest he should not be in the highest Manner obliged by it; and which it must be impossible he ever can, with any Sence of Gratitude, forget; which Letter is of such Consequence in the present Argument, that we could by no Means omit to incert it, as that upon which his whole Affair at that Time depended; and in Consequence whereof, he was in Spight of French Opposition elected Emperor, even before he set his Foot on the Coast of Italy.

Here follows the Translation of the Let∣ter, written by the States-General of the Ʋnited Provinces, with the Conjunct Ap∣probation of the British Embassador at the Hague to King Charles III. dated 27th of April, 1711.

LETTER.P:
'TIS with an extream Grief that we have been informed of the Death of his Im∣perial Majesty, and we would not defer One Moment to let your Majesty know how much
we are sensible of the great Loss you sustain by the Death of a Dear Brother, who was the Chief and Main Support of the Alliances; so dismal and unexpected an Accident cannot but cause some Alteration in the Minds of People, but we hope it will occasion no Change in, or Prejudice to, the Publick Affairs; and that the Prudence of the High Allies will hinder the Enemy from reaping any Advantage thereby; we believe that the best they can do in this Juncture is to continue strictly united, and prosecute the War with Firmness, without any Alteration in the Measures that have been con∣certed, and in particular in those Relative to the Affair of Spain; these being our Senti∣ments, we assure your Majesty we will conti∣nue to contribute our utmost Efforts for pro∣moting and supporting the Common Cause, and your Interest in particular; not doubting but your Majesty, according to your great Wisdom and Zeal for the Publick Good, will also do on your Part all that will be in your Power, as well for preserving and augmenting the good Correspondence and Ʋnion between the Allies, as for promoting the Common Cause, and in particular for supporting the Affairs in Spain, for which we believe the Efforts ought not to be in the least lessened, desiring your Majesty to take as much Care thereof as possible; we have ordered, and do now order again, our Vice-Admiral Picterson, who is at present in the Mediterranean, to concert with your Majesty, and the Commander of the Fleet of Her Maje∣sty
of Great-Britain, and the Measures that shall be found necessary in the present Conjuncture, and do whatsoever shall be in common concert thought more useful; mean Time, as the Im∣perial Throne is vacant, we have written to the Princes, Electors of the Empire, to re∣present, that it cannot be more worthily filled than by your Majesty, whose Interest we have recommended to them in the Election, which is to be made according to the Constitutions of the Empire; we hope that this Evidence of our strict Adherences to your Majesty, and our Zeal for your Service, will not be disagreeable to you; and that when Occasion shall offer your Majesty will also have some Regard for the In∣terest of our Republick, and be perswaded that we shall earnestly look for Opportunity to show more and more to your Majesty the great Esteem we put on your Friendship and Affection; as to the rest, we pray God to preserve your Majesty in Good Health, and grant you what∣ever you wish.

DIV2.P: Nor was this all, but the subsequent Proceeding, both of the States-General, and of the Queen of Great-Britain, were every way agreeable, and conforming to the sincere Professions of Concern and Re∣spect, mentioned in this Letter.

It would be too long here to Recapitulate the several Steps farther taken in their Inte∣rest of this Prince, and which make up the whole History of his Election. How
the Confederates broke all the Measures of the Campaign in Flanders, parted with a great Detachment of the Army, and there∣by weakened the rest, so as not to be able to undertake the great Designs they had projected for that Summer, sacrificing the whole Expence of the Campaign to strengthen his Interest, and to make him appear so Formidable on the Rhine, as that the French could offer no Disturbance to the Assembly at Frankfort, or in any Mea∣sure Awe or Influence the Election. How, in Pursuance of the aforesaid Letter, the Confederate Fleet in the Mediterranean were given up wholly to his Majesty King Charles's Orders, as well to Transport and Convoy him from Catalonia to Italy, as to Carry and Convoy the Troops and Sup∣plies he should want to support his Affairs in Spain; and in short, how by these Things his Election was secured and effected, his Person Safely Landed, and himself put into that Posture of Power, and that Figure in the Affairs of Christendom, which we see this Day.

These Things, we say, it would be too tedious here to relate, wherefore we chuse to refer the Reader to the Accounts of those Things published in other Tracts, in all which the Share Her Majesty, and Her Allies, have constantly had in the Gran∣deur and Interest of this very Grate∣ful
Monarch, have been plainly set down.

Come we next to the Affair of the Trea∣ty of Peace, in which the first Beginnings of the Retribution, and subsequent Behavi∣our of his Majesty, to his aforesaid Friends, is the Thing we are to enquire into.

The Proposals of France, of which so much Noise has been made, were in the Month of October, or thereabouts, made to Her Britannick Majesty by the French King, and Sign'd by his Agent here, Mon∣sieur Mesnager; a Thing so Publick, no far∣ther Account needs to be given of it here; nor that these Proposals were immediately communicated to the Ministers of all the Allies by the Queen's Order, that they might be sent to their respective Prin∣cipals, and their Answers thereupon be ob∣tain'd.

When the first News of this Matter came to the Knowledge of King Charles, a little before his Election, we find him at his Landing near Genoa, when he came from Barcelona, expressing himself warmly to Her Majesties Ambassador, Mr. Chetwynd, when he waited on him on Board the Eng∣lish Fleet, to Compliment him upon his Arrival in Italy, in this Manner.

“”That if the Queen proceeded in this Manner, he should be obliged to take Care of himself, and that the other Allies would do the same after his Example. Vide Observations on the Hannover Memorial. P. 16.

This is the first Instance from whence we derive the Title of our Book, and which we think gives us some Idea of what we call IMPERIAL GRATITUDE. This Language sounds a little harsh to the very Pen, after it has been writing so ma∣ny fine, soft, and smooth Things, as have hitherto supplied these Pages; this is some∣thing different from the Expressions of, Ever bound to remember; Eternal Gratitude; overcome with Her Majesties Goodness; and the like; so that one would think they could hardly proceed from the same Mouth.

But we are not to stop here, let us go on. The Proposals of France, vulgarly and er∣roneously call'd Preliminaries, coming to his Majesties Hands, from his Ambassador Count Gallas; and the Proposals of a Treaty at Ʋtrecht being made, besides that his Majesty thought not fit to expostulate it with the Queen immediately, let us see what Treatment the Queen, and the whole British Nation, meets with from him, in his Letter to the Elector Palatine, and the
Princes of the Empire, and in his Letter to the States of Holland, on the Subject of the said Treaty and Preliminaries; and tho' these Letters are long, we cannot content ourselves to omit them, because of the dif∣ferent Stile from what we have read and quoted before; and because, as we pro∣mised in the Beginning of this Work, we shall all along chuse rather to quote you his Majesties own Words, than to give you the Comments and Explanations thereon, which however just, may be more liable to Exception.

First then, we give you his Imperial Ma∣jesties Letter Circular, directed more imme∣diately to the Elector Palatine, but also sent to all the Electors and Princes of the Em∣pire, concern'd in furnishing their Quota's to the War, as follows.

THAT his Majesty did not question but that his Electoral Highness had been in∣formed of the Preliminaries of Peace proposed in England, on the Part of France, a Copy of which is here subjoined, and was no less con∣cerned than his Majesty, that at a Time when God had so largely bestowed his Blessing on the Arms of the Allies, and when there was just Grounds to hope to reduce the Enemy within just Bounds, for the securing the Tran∣quility of Europe, that Crown should offer such Proposals, which had not only been hear∣kened to at London, but had also been com∣municated
in Form the 9th of October to Count Gallas, Minister of his Majesty, by a Secretary of State, and proposed in Holland as acceptable, with earnest Instances of entring into a Negotiation thereupon: That hitherto his Majesty had been unwilling to look upon this Precipitation as a departing from the Aim and Intention of the Grand Alliance, seeing the Obligation the Allies are under, not to enter into any Negotiations of a separate Peace, is sufficiently known by all the World, according to the Treaty of Alliance; and there∣fore was rather enclined to believe, that the, had too easily given Credit to the captious Pro∣posals of the Enemy, though they were not so well varnished as others have been; for every one perceived at first Sight that hardly any one Thing in them was clearly expressed, and that the Enemies Design was to gain Time by a long Negotiation, as well for recovering themselves, as for dividing the Allies, which they have endeavoured to do a long Time since; that it was not difficult to foresee the Conse∣quences, if Men would only consider with At∣tention, that since, with so great Effusion of Blood, and unconceivable Expence, the united Forces of the Allies have not yet been able to obtain the Principal End of the War, that is, the common Security and Tranquility of Eu∣rope, what more can be expected from a sepa∣rate Peace, or its Fxecution, than what has happened, in Respect to the Solemn Oaths of the Renunciation at the Pyrenees, and other En∣gagements,
which were to be perpetual, and especially when the French shall be Masters of the Forces of Spain, Indies, and all the Commerce.

As for us, (continues the Emperor,) we hope the contrary, and are entirely perswaded that you will be of the same Opinion, insomuch, that you will not only oppose those Designs that are pernicious to the Common Cause, accord∣ing to your Renowned Zeal for your Country, but also that you will powerfully use your great Credit with the Electors and States of the Empire, and also with the States-General of the United Netherlands, and other Allies, as we affectionately desire of you, by the near Tie of Blood there is between us, that you may all persevere together in the Engagements of the Alliance, and in the necessary Ʋnion, for obtaining an Advantagious and Solid Peace, and that in England they may, following this laudable Example, desist from any Thoughts that are contrary, and entertain such as are conformable thereto.

In the mean Time we have taken an irre∣vocable Resolution to undergo whatever may come of it, and to exert all our Efforts for the Good of the Common Cause, exposing even our own Person, rather than consent to the sending of any one in our Name, to assist in a Partial Negotiation, entirely ruinous to our Dear Country, and the Liberty of all Europe, and which we could not answer to our Archdu∣cal House.

We have thought fit to represent to you these Things without Delay, as to an Elector, and an Ally so particularly Interested in this War, to the End you may assist us with your Council and Endeavours, to the strengthning the Grand Alliance, for which we, and our Archducal House, will preserve an Eternal Gratitude, &c.

At the same Time, or near it, his Maje∣sty thought fit to Write to the States-Gene∣ral the following Letter; as to the Queen of England, whether it was because the Imperial Envoy, and Resident, Count Gal∣las, had affronted the Queen, and been re∣fused here, or for what other Reason, we do not determine; his Imperial Majesty never took any Notice to Her, or of Her, never so much as returned the Acknow∣ledgments, formerly so frequent with him, as to the Assistance received in his Election, or took any Notice of the Preliminaries at all, at least that we have heard of, but in his Letter to the States-General he writes thus.

LETTER.P:
BY Letters that are just come to us from the Hague we have received Advice, that the Ambassador of England is returned into your Provinces, and has brought with him some New Preliminary Articles of Peace, proposed by the King of France, drawn up
with great Artifice, and altogether such as must be expected from an Enemy, for they con∣tain nothing but what is dubious and equivo∣cal; and if one takes the Pains to examine thoroughly the Sence they impart, instead of the indefinite Terms which appear at the first View, one will clearly find therein the Loss which can never be sufficiently deplored of, the Spanish Monarchy; for which only, and for preserving it in our Imperial Family, and at the same Time for maintaining the Peace of Europe, this War was underta∣ken; Ten Years have been spent in Fight∣ing, and so much Blood spilt, so that nothing more dismal, and more fatal, could happen in the World.

For who is not sensible, that if this great Augmentation of Power be left in Addition to that of the Enemy, all those in general who are Confederated in this War, and each of them in Particular, can expect nothing but a more shameful Slavery, from which hitherto we have been able to save ourselves; that he thereby renders himself Master of our Liberties, and that he is endeavouring with insupportable Arrogance to impose on us in his Turn the Laws he was of late obliged to receive? Fur∣thermore, should the War continue in such a Manner, that the Enemy, already weakned by his ill Successes, should come at last to be a Victor, yet it would be still unpardonable to consent to such unjust Preliminaries.

But at present, when he cannot look in the Face of the Armies of the Allies, when he is not secure anywhere, neither in the Field, nor in his fortified Towns; when having lost part of his Forces, and his Places, he is a∣fraid that very suddenly the War will be carried into the Heart of his Kingdom; can one help being justly irritated against those who have been so often deceived by the Illusion of the French, will venture to try once more the good Faith, which they always promise, but never keep, give Assistance to those Enemies, abandon their Allies, renounce their Alliances, and in a Word, make use of their own Victories, to prepare a Yoke for their own Posterity?

Certainly, if it were not visible to the whole World, that the King of France, by proposing these Preliminaries, designs, according to his Custom, under pretext of an Assembly for treating of Peace, to divide the Allies, and create a Misunderstanding among them by his usual Artifices, which have always hitherto sup∣plied him with Means to illude what has been agreed, at least a sad Remembrance of what is past ought to be sufficient for rendering the Thing more than Evident, and to have set it continually before our Eyes; this Reason has chiefly induced us to think that there is no other Solid Foundation upon which the Peace to be made can be established, then to fix the Incon∣stancy of France by such Preliminary Arti∣cles, that She may no longer surprize others, and extricate Herself by an unjust Treaty of
Peace, as She has done on every Occasion hi∣therto.

We do not at all doubt that you will likewise persist in these Sentiments, and join your De∣liberations with ours, to seek Means to induce the Queen of Great-Britain, and, if possible, to engage Her to reject those Propositions, and to continue the War or else, if a Negotiation with the Enemy must be entered upon, that it may be on Condition, that the proceeding Pre∣liminaries proposed most of them by the Ene∣my himself, may remain fix'd, and without Alteration; and so that She will not trust the Immortal Glory he has acquired, and the certain Welfare of Her People, to the Infidelity of the Promises of the French, of what Kind soever they may be.

'Tis for these Reasons that we earnestly in∣treat, and most effectionately exhort you, that, according to your usual Generosity, you will take with us the Resolution to support that Cause, which is now in so great Danger, and not suffer the deceitful Intrigues of France to have a successful Issue through our Remissness, and turn our Triumphs to our Shame and Dishonour.

As for us, whatever Consequences may en∣sue from this Affair, we utterly reject these Preliminaries, as well for the present as for the future; and we will not by any Means im∣power our Ambassadors to assist at the Confe∣rences which are proposed for treating upon them, but rather we will exort all our Efforts,
as we are actually doing, that our Armies, particularly those in Catalonia, may be re∣established and reinforced, that all the World may be convinced that it is in no wise any Fault of ours that the War is not carried on to a Happy Issue; and that a Peace, Firm, Lasting, and Advantageous, to all the Allies is not restored to the whole Ʋniverse. For the rest we are, &c.

DIV2.P: Thus far his Imperial Majesties own Words; how oddly they sound, how harsh, how unlike his Letters from Lisbon and from Barcelona, let the Reader determine; we are loth to Comment upon them, lest in doing Justice to the Queen we should be obliged to handle his Majesty too se∣verely.

We must conclude these Remarks with descending to a brief History of Fact, as it now relates to the Peace, and the Con∣duct of this Grateful Person to Her Majesty, in the Negotiations that are now on Foot: Pursuant to the irrevocable Determination of the King of Spain, we find him refusing, even before he is ask'd, the First Question, or Proposal, his Great Maternal Benefac∣tress, the Queen of Great-Britain, was like to make to him; and after the Proposal was made to him from the Queen, by an especial Messenger, which carried Her Ma∣jesties
Letter, written to all the Allies, his Imperial Majesty's Answer, for he was now Elected Emperor, contain'd a posi∣tive Denial to come to any Treaty, or to send any Plenipotentiaries to the Congress at Ʋtrecht. The Justice and Equity of the Denial turns upon Two or Three Things.
1. The Reason and Justice of Her Ma∣jesties Request.
2. The Obligation upon his Imperial Majesty, to the Person of the Queen, and to the British Court proposing.
3. The Weight of the Reasons alledged against it.

The first of these, (viz.) the Reason and Justice of Her Majesties Proposal, is best to be seen by the Proposal itself, and that is exprest in the said Circular Letter, which was sent, as by its Title appears, to all the Princes concern'd in the Grand Alliance, of whom his Imperial Majesty was not only one, but the Chief; the Letter is as fol∣lows.

THE most Christian King having ac∣quainted us with his Desire to see the Quiet and Tranquility of Furope restored, by a Safe and Honourable Peace for us, and all our High Allies, and having made some Offers to
dispose us to the opening of Conferences for that Purpose, (which Offers have been communi∣cated to all the said Allies,) and the States-Ge∣neral having thereupon declared, that they are inclined, and ready to enter into a Negotiation for a Good and General Peace, and to join with us, for inviting the Powers engaged with us in the present War, to send their Ministers and Plenipotentiaries to the Congress; and the Place and Time of which having been concerted with the Minister of the said States-General, we have thought it necessary to let you know, without any Loss of Time, that we have agreed to affix the Opening of the said Congress to the 12th of January next, N. S. in the Town of Utrecht; as we have no other View than to put an End to this War by a Solid Peace, and in which every one of the Allies may find a reasonable Satisfaction, we doubt not but you will be equally disposed to contribute to the Advancement of so Pious and Benefi∣cial a Work. Wherefore we desire you to send forthwith the Ministers whom you shall appoint for that Purpose, that by the Time a∣bove specified they may appear in the said Town of Utrecht.

Furthermore, we think it convenient to acquaint you, that we have resolved, in con∣cert with the States-General, to send our Mi∣nisters to the Congress only in the Quality of Plenipotentiaries, and that they shall not take upon them the Character of Ambassadors, till the Day of the Signing of the Peace, in or∣der
to avoid, as much as possible, the Diffi¦culties of the Ceremoniale and the Delay▪ which might be occasioned thereby.

Notwithstanding this Letter, his Impe∣rial Majesty refused peremptorily to send any Ambassadors or Plenipotentiaries to Ʋtrecht. This we call denying to the Queen the first Request, or Proposal, which Her Majesty made to him, notwithstanding the Kindness and Concern shew'd to him by Her Majesty in other, and on former, Oc∣casions.

As to the Second Head, (viz.) the Obli∣gation upon his Imperial Majesty to the Person of the Queen, it may relate to the Queen Two Ways; first, the Obligation of Gratitude for former Kindness shewn him, and the Obligation of Justice to the Reasonableness of Her Majesties Proposal, which only signified a Desire in the Queen to have his Imperial Majesty, and all the rest of Her Allies, receive entire Satisfaction in the design'd Treaty; all Her View there∣in being, as She exprest there, to make a Firm and Solid Peace, &c. and that they should meet there to treat thereof, and see if it was possible for them to agree about it.

Now, though the Obligations we speak of upon his Imperial Majesty might not be reasonably expected to be sufficient to influ∣ence him in the Matters of the Peace itself,
yet sure, to the Ceremony of a Treaty, something might be argued; and it seem'd to many, a Token of small Respect to Her Majesty, that the Emperor should stand out from a Meeting only, when the first Proposal of that Meeting came from a Prince, which he had so good Reason to think had his particular Interest at Heart; and a Prince, who had given him such convincing Proofs of it, by such a Series of Benefaction, as is the Subject of the first Part of this Treatise.

How surprizing then must it be to find, instead of this, such Expressions relating to the British Court, such Arguments, im∣plying a Diffidence in, and Resolution to oppose all the Measures taken for a Peace, and particular, a Determination to refuse so much as to oblige the Queen of Great-Britain in the trifling Request, of coming together to treat.

Had a Treaty been begun, and any Proposals entred upon there, been contra∣ry to the Interest, Inclination, or other Views of his Imperial Majesty, and he had stood out from a Compliance, he might then indeed have had a Pretence, he had his Reasons, his Interest, and his other Views, to have offered as Reasons, and whether they had been sufficient, or no, the Liberty every one had to determine of that might have left it the Opinion of the World: But the Pretence of, and Right to
make Objections, had been Just and Re∣sonable; but to refuse to treat, to refuse so much as to send Plenipotentiaries, or Ambassadors, to hear what should be of∣fered, and to judge whether it was suffici∣cient, or a ground of Satisfaction, yea, or no, this favour'd of too much Disre∣gard to the Proposer, to come from any Prince who had own'd himself under such Engagements and Obligations to the said Proposer, as his Imperial Majesty had done to the Queen of Great-Britain; and this the rather, because it was rejecting, not a Ma∣terial Thing, but a Circumstance, a Point of Ceremony, a Thing frequently, and on many occasions, left by one Prince to ano∣ther; and therefore the refusing this to the Queen of Great-Britain could but signifie some Diffidence, Distrust and Uneasiness in the Refuser of, and at the Proposer; and what Reasons there can be for that in his Majesty, as it respects the Queen of Great-Britain, let any one that has read the former Sheets of this Tract determine; indeed we cannot but think it seems at least to us very disrespectful; as to the Word ungrate∣ful, we are loth to call it by so harsh a Name; perhaps it may be the Manner by which those Northern Nations of the World exprest their Gratitude for infinite Obliga∣tions, and for Kindnesses too great for them, by any other Method to requite; and this may the better suit the Terms of our Title,
and may be left on Record, as a true Test of what is called Imperial Gratitude.
But to come to the Third Head, (viz.) the Weight of the Reasons alledged in Be∣half of his Imperial Majesty for his refusing to treat, and these may merit some Consi∣deration.

The first we meet with in all the foregoing Letters, is that he cannot consent to treat on the Foot of the said Seven Preliminaries; many that strove hard to defend his Impe∣rial Majesty in his standing out, and refusing to come to treat, gave this as a Reason, that he did by no means pretend to object against a Treaty in General, but against a Treaty upon the Foot of those Preliminaries, as Things altogether insufficient, and uncapa∣ble of founding a Safe and Honourable Peace, and as Things which at their very first View seem'd to take it for granted, or at least openly suggest, the giving up the Spanish Monarchy to the Enemy. That if a Treaty were set on Foot on the Preliminaries for∣merly adjusted, and upon Conditions suitable to his Imperial Majesties Pretensions, and to that Right he had to the Spanish Monarchy, which was owned by all the Confederates, that then he was ready, in Concert with his Allies, &c. but he could not enter upon such a Treaty as he understood this to be; what Measures Her Britannick Majesty took to open his Eyes in this Respect, and to sa∣tisfie him that She did not understand the
Proposals in such a Manner; that she desired that his Imperial Majesty should, as well as all Her other Allies, receive full Satisfaction in the Treaty, and the like; and how little such a Declaration was of Effect, to alter his Majesties said Resolutions, or to encou∣rage him to have Confidence in Her said Majesty, who had formerly been so zealous for his Interest, and in whom he had ex∣pressed before such entire Confidence, we need not enquire.

2. The next Reason we meet with in his Majesties Representations against this Trea∣ty was the Ambiguity of the Expressions, which being of double Entendre, doubtful Construction, and a various Signification, should be Construed in the Execution of them, to the Advantage of the Enemy, and tended manifestly to amuse and divide the Confederates; it may be confessed, that had these Proposals been the only Foundation, and that they were, as before, supposed to be the Heads, to which the Plenipotentiaries were limited in their Treaty, there had been more to be said on this Head, but otherwise it seem'd to argue strongly, that a fair and open Treaty of a Peace was the only Way for all the Confederates to determine the direct Sense of every Article, to oblige France to explain herself upon any Point that might seem ambiguous, and to remove all possible Constructions which might be put upon them, to the Prejudice of any
Part of the Allies; and had his Majesty spo∣ken or thought in this Case, with the same Sentiments that he had appeared to speak and think with before, (viz.) of an entire Confidence in, and Dependance upon, Her Majesty of Great-Britain, from whom he had received such frequent and undoubted Evidences of a true and of a deep Con∣cern for him, and for his Interest, we might rather have expected some Expressi∣ons like these; Having an entire Confidence in Your Majesties good Affection to us, and to our Interest, which You have in so many Occa∣sions, with so generous a Concern, and so much Goodness, so many Ways expressed; and that You will not suffer any Thing to be done, agreed to, or granted, to the Prejudice of our Right, and the Loss or Dammage of our Interest, at the said Treaty, &c. This, or something like this, had been all of a Piece with the rest; and the Spirit and Vigour of a Mind obliged in the highest Manner, and sensible of the greatest Favours, had appeared here, as it did in the Letters of the same Prince, formerly quoted: But his Majesty was not now Besieged within the Walls of Barcelona, he was now Exalted to the Imperial Dig∣nity; he was not now surrounded by a French Army, and a Breach of Fifty Paces Wide made in the Fortifications he had to defend; he is now surrounded with the Ac∣clamations of the Germans, attended by in∣numerable Crowds, and throng'd with a
Concourse of Princes, instead of a Formi∣dable Fleet blocking him up by Sea, and his Rival ready to seize him, and carry him in Triumph to Madrid; he is entring in Triumph the Imperial Cities of Germany; instead of the roaring of the Cannon from the Batteries in the Enemies Approaches, he hears the thundring of Cannon from the Ramparts of the Towns he passes through; and instead of the Cries of the Assailants at∣tempting to Storm the only City, he hears the Shouts of long Live the Emperor, Vive il Rey d' Espaign, and the like; and if these Things have altered his Stile a little, and caused him to forget the Expressions which formerly came with so much Freedom from him in his Distress, we cannot so much Wonder, since nothing is so natural to the Constitution of Man as to resent Injury, and forget Favours.

3. We might in all his Representations abovesaid, observe another Reason why his Imperial Majesty has thus stifly, we had almost said obstinately, rejected a Treaty; and this is the clear View he seems to have, that in such Treaty he may be required by his Allies to part with some Branches of the Spanish Monarchy, either for the Satisfaction of his Allies, for the immense Expences, Losses, and Dammages of the War, or for the more easie inducing the Enemy, by a quiet De∣mission to put him in Possession of the rest, where that we may do Justice to his Impe∣rial
Majesty; it seems that this Reason has not so little Weight in it as some may think it has; particularly, that his Imperial Ma∣jesty may think he is now vested with new Powers, and placed in a Station able to make a more powerful Figure in the Alli∣ance than he has hitherto done; that the Efforts he shall now make are so considerable as ought to encourage the Allies to push on farther, without Regard to the particular Interests that may otherwise move them. We are loth to say that his Imperial Maje∣sty too soon overlooks the exhausted Cir∣cumstances of most of Europe, and particu∣larly some Nations, especially weakened and exhausted by their Zeal for his imme∣diate Assistance, and that they are obliged to have no regard to any Thing but the fair Opportunity that now offers to re-esta∣blish him in the Possession of New King∣doms, not looking at all into their own. We are loth to look back into the Circum∣stances of the War, and give for Reasons, that the Weight of the War lying principal∣ly upon the Confederates, and the Gain of any Conquests, or Acquistion, falling in General into the Hands of the Emperor; and that the Gain to the Emperor, by carry∣ing on the War, is beyond all Comparison, so much greater than the Expence of his Part, that therefore it is not to be expected that such Forwardness for a Peace should appear on his Side, as those States and
Princes might show who have borne the Weight of that War, and have their Eyes fix'd only on the Native and Settled Advan∣tages attending a Safe and Honourable Peace.

But come we therefore a little to enquire wherein these Reasons seem not insufficient, only but a little unkind, with Respect to the Nations who have with so much Can∣dour and Generosity engaged to assist and carry on his Imperial Majesty, and to whose Influence he owes so much, the Establish∣ment of his Affairs in their present Happy and Flourishing Posture.

Her Majesty had not given the least Oc∣casion for his Imperial Majesty to think She would make a Separate or Disadvantageous Treaty; or that the Loss of Spain to his Imperial and Arch-Ducal House would be the necessary Consequence of such a Treaty; but on the contrary, as well by Her private Assurances to all Her Allies, as in Her Speech to the British Parliament, Her Majesty had given all possible Assuran∣ces that She was resolved at the said Treaty to obtain full Satisfaction to all Her Allies; and that She had their Interest at Heart, that She would enter into such Engagements with the Allies as should effectually secure and obtain such Satisfaction; and that She was resolved, if such Satisfaction could not be obtained, to carry on the War with the utmost Vigour. This was so clear a Decla∣ration of the sincere Intentions of Her Maje∣sty
in the View of a Peace, that immediate∣ly gave Satisfaction, not only to Her own Subjects at Home, but to all the rest of the Allies Abroad; and upon which imme∣diately the Plenipotentiaries of the other Allies were nominated, and began to move towards the Place of the Treaty, and made ready for the Congress.

Farther than this, Her Majesty failed not to explain Herself upon the Affair of the Pro∣posals of France, That they were understood only as Proposals, That it was Her Intention nevertheless that all the Allies should enter into, as well their General as their parti∣cular Demands, at the Treaty, and should Treat upon the Subject of their proper In∣terests and Satisfaction, as if no such Propo∣sals or Preliminaries had been made.

It were too much to enter into all the particular Steps taken by Her Majesty in this Affair, to satisfie, if possible, all the reasonable just Scruples of his Imperial Ma∣jesty; and yet, after all, if we may be∣lieve the Foreign Accounts, we find him still diffident; that he has not yet agreed to send his Plenipotentiaries; and, as those Accounts say, that he expects a Declaration in Writing from Her Majesty, that those Articles shall not be treated on as Prelimi∣naries, &c.

If this be so, tho', as we said before, we shall not charge his Imperial Majesty with Unreasonable Jealousies, Groundless Dis∣trusts, and acting with less Regard to the
Honour and Dignity of Her Britannick Ma∣jesty, than he has just Occasion given him to do; yet we cannot but represent these diffe∣rent Schemes to the View of every Impartial Reader, and laying one by the other, de∣sire and recommend it to them, to compare them together, and see if it can be imagin'd they can come from the same Hand; or that if they do, whether they are not very Sin∣gular in several Things, and may not be very properly stated to the World, and put into such Form, as the like may always be known by the Title given to this Book, (viz.) Imperial Ingratitude.

DIV1.HEAD: CONCLUSION.
DIV1.P: WHAT has been laid down here needs very little Comment, you have a Scetch of the Conduct of a Confede∣rate of the first Magnitude in his various Changes and Circumstances, and you have it laid down with no Deviation from Fact; the Case, as it lyes before you now, is all History, and the Reader is led to such un∣questioned Vouchers, as it may be suggest∣ed will admit no Debate, Ex Ore Tuo is the Word; and truly, in a Case of such Con∣cern as this, it seems that no less Evidence ought to be admitted, for many Reasons, the Subject being of the highest Consequence, and the Person spoken of Supream in Dig∣nity, the first Potentate in Christendom.

It remains now, by Way of Conclusion, to look a little from the Person we have
been speaking of, and to consider our own Circumstances, to look before us, and en∣quire what Measures we ought to take, how the British Court stands obliged to act, and how to behave in the Affair of the Treaty, with Respect to a Prince that has acted by our Government, as before related.

It is a Thing Notorious, if we look back to consider this Prince as King of Spain, only that he is under Obligations to us, but we are under none to him; if we look back on him as Emperor, then he stands on the Step from which the late Emperor, and his other Ancestors, went off; in which Capa∣city we may do no unnecessary Duty to ask on which Side lyes the Obligation.

In order to this Enquiry, it is not impro∣per to propose to those who are so full of the Emperor's Merit as a Confederate, that they would let us see with what a kind of Concern, for the general Interest of the Al∣lies, the Emperors have carried on the War, how they have supplied their Quota's, how filled their Military Chest, and their Maga∣zines, and in what Posture they have been as to the War; let them give us a Descripti∣on of the Imperial Conduct, and state it with the Obligation which lay on that Court as a Confederate, and what the Al∣lies ought to have expected from them. Let them enquire, and set down for the Peru∣sal of the World, what Share of Diversion to the Enemies Troops the Emperor has ta∣ken upon him; let the Battles, the Sieges,
the Armies on the Ʋpper Rhine, be reckoned up▪ and above all, let them set down the Times of the Year when those Armies gene∣rally came into the Field, and when they left it, how far they march'd, how long they kept Garrison in their Lines, and how well also they defended them when attack'd also by the French, with Forces not Superior to them.

It is much talked here now of what Great Forces the Emperor is preparing to bring in∣to the Field, and those who give reasonable Accounts of them, (as for the extravagant Ac∣counts of others they are worth no Notice in this Place,) make them 90000 Men, but these People forget to look back upon the Quota's, which in Consequence of the Grand Alliance it was agreed the Imperial Court was to bring into the Field, and there it will appear that 91750 Men was the Compliment his Imperial Majesty was obliged to furnish over and above the Troops of the Empire: Now if ever one half of these were brought into the Field, or appeared in Action, if ever these Capitulations were perform'd, let these Gen∣tlemen set down the Names of the Regiments, and where, and when, they serv'd; if they had been in the Field perhaps the Work had not been left to do at this Time of Day; and if they have not been produced, then it re∣mains to ask, whether it is reasonable that we should carry on the War to oblige, and in dependance upon, the Promises o SUCH an Ally?
